candidates.title: Did a Pink Volcano Erupt in New Zealand?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A video shows a pink volcano erupting in New Zealand.
Rating:
False
About this rating
A video purportedly showing bright fuschia smoke billowing from a volcano frequently appears on social media, along with a claim that it shows an actual "pink volcano" erupting in New Zealand:
Pink eruption of the volcano in New Zealand
The video does not explain what chemical process might turn smoke or steam this particular shade (although with the proper dyes, it is possible to turn smoke into a veritable rainbow), but it isn't particularly relevant anyway; this video does not depict an actual volcanic eruption.
The "pink volcano" video was created by artist Filip Hodas, and was originally shared to his Facebook page in December 2016. Hodas posted the video to Instagram (with tags such as #3D, #photoshop, #render, and #animation), and provided extra insight into how the video was created in response to a query on Facebook:
pretty much! depends on what I need. In this case I layered few planes with wm maps on top of each other and added a lot of zdepth fog to blend it in.
No records of volcanos emitting bright pink smoke exist, except those created by digital artists.
candidates.description: Video purportedly showing oddly-colored smoke and steam rising from a eruption was digitally manipulated.

result.explanation: The news caption "An actual \"pink volcano\" erupting in New Zealand" is directly contradicted by the provided evidence. Snopes.com fact-check explicitly states that the video showing a pink volcano eruption in New Zealand is digitally manipulated and false.  The fact-check cites the creator of the video and details how it was created using digital art techniques. No evidence supports the existence of a naturally occurring pink volcano eruption.

final_result.explanation: Both internal and external validation checks strongly indicate that the original caption, "An actual \"pink volcano\" erupting in New Zealand," is inaccurate and out of context. The internal check highlights a discrepancy: while the image depicts a plume of pink and purple smoke resembling a volcanic eruption, it does not confirm the location (New Zealand) or the authenticity of the event as a naturally occurring phenomenon.  The confidence score of 8 reflects this uncertainty regarding location and natural origin. However, the external check provides definitive evidence from Snopes.com, a reputable fact-checking website. Snopes's investigation revealed that the video (and likely the image) depicting the pink volcanic eruption is digitally manipulated, not a genuine event.  The fact-check provides substantial evidence that the video was created by an artist, Filip Hodas, using digital art techniques. The confidence score of 10 for the external check highlights the certainty of this information, supported by cited sources and detailed explanation of the video's creation.  The conflict between the internal and external checks is resolved by prioritizing the external evidence. Since the external check conclusively proves the event was digitally fabricated, the original caption is demonstrably false.  The high confidence scores from both checks (8 and 10), coupled with the conclusive external evidence, lead to a final confidence score of 10, reflecting the high certainty that the caption is out of context. No ambiguity remains regarding the authenticity of the image or its representation of a real pink volcanic eruption in New Zealand.  The external evidence directly refutes the claim made in the caption.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validation strongly reject the caption. Internal validation notes visual resemblance to a volcanic eruption but lacks location and authenticity confirmation. External validation definitively proves the image is digitally manipulated, not a real event, based on Snopes's fact-check. The final assessment is that the caption is out of context.
